skill.name: commit-helper
skill.description: Expert conventional commits assistant for the Logseq Template Graph project. Analyzes git changes and generates proper conventional commit messages with correct type, scope, and format. Use when the user needs help writing commits or validating commit messages.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code. All 249 static findings are false positives: documentation examples showing git commands (not execution), commit message format strings misinterpreted as cryptographic patterns, and version strings flagged as C2 keywords. This is a safe documentation skill.

content.value_statement: Writing clear commit messages is challenging. This skill analyzes your git changes and suggests properly formatted conventional commits with correct type, scope, and description. It validates format and explains the reasoning behind each suggestion.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes staged and unstaged git changes using git diff and git status commands
Determines correct commit type based on file changes (feat, fix, docs, refactor, etc.)
Suggests appropriate scope for commit messages tailored to project structure
Validates commit message format against conventional commits standard
Generates multi-line commit messages with body and footer sections
Detects breaking changes and suggests appropriate exclamation mark notation
limitations: Project-specific scopes are tailored for Logseq Template Graph (templates, classes, properties, ci)
Does not execute git commit command - requires user to run the command manually
Does not push changes to remote repositories
Cannot access remote git history or branches not available locally

output_examples.input: Suggest a commit message for my staged changes
output: feat(classes): add Recipe class to creative-work module
- Type: feat (new class is a feature)
To commit: git commit -m "feat(classes): add Recipe class to creative-work module"

output_examples.input: I fixed a bug in the spouse property cardinality
output: fix(properties): correct spouse property cardinality to :many
- Body: Explains WHY the fix was needed
To commit: git commit -m "fix(properties): correct spouse property cardinality to :many"

output_examples.input: My changes include a breaking change that removes the Customer class
output: BREAKING CHANGE: Customer class removed from template.
Use Person class with customerRole property instead.
1. Export all pages using Customer class

best_practices: Always check staged changes first with git diff --cached before suggesting commits
Use imperative mood for descriptions (add, not added; fix, not fixed)
Include body text when changes need explanation or reference issues and pull requests
anti_patterns: Using past tense in descriptions (Fixed bug instead of fix bug)
Omitting type and scope (just description without feat or fix prefix)
Ending descriptions with periods or exceeding 72 characters in the subject line

faq.question: Does this skill commit changes to git?
faq.answer: No. This skill only suggests and validates commit messages. You must run git commit yourself with the suggested message.

faq.question: What commit types does this skill support?
faq.answer: Standard types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ops, chore. It also detects breaking changes marked with !.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with any git repository?
faq.answer: Yes, but project-specific scopes work best with Logseq Template Graph. For other projects, use generic scopes.

faq.question: Is my code or git history sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-only skill. All git commands run locally on your machine. No data is transmitted externally.

faq.question: Why does the skill need git command access?
faq.answer: Git commands are essential to read staged changes. Commands run locally and are necessary to analyze what files changed.

faq.question: How is this different from other commit tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides context-aware suggestions based on actual file changes. It validates format and explains reasoning for each suggestion.
